headline.main-hed: Putin Is Circumspect on Re-Election but Says ‘Nyet’ to Presidency for Life

alt-summary-body.p: Russian President Vladimir Putin said he doesn’t aim to hold his post for life but doesn’t rule out seeking another term in 2018.

headline.main-hed: Putin is circumspect on re-election but says ‘nyet’ to presidency for life

summary-body.p: Russian President Vladimir Putin said he doesn’t aim to hold his post for life but doesn’t rule out seeking another term in 2018.

headline.main-hed: Putin Is Circumspect on Re-Election but Says ‘Nyet’ to Presidency for Life
headline.deck: Russian President Calls Western Sanctions Against Moscow a ‘Gross Violation of Human Rights’

media.media-caption: Russian President Vladimir Putin, shown this month in Vladivostok, Russia, told the TASS news agency that he won’t rule out running for re-election in 2018, and that Western sanctions against Moscow violate human rights.

article-body.p: MOSCOW—Russian President Vladimir Putin said he doesn’t aim to hold his post for life but doesn’t rule out seeking another term in 2018, a move that could make him the country’s longest-serving leader since Joseph Stalin.

In an interview with state-controlled TASS news agency, the 62-year-old Mr. Putin said that for him to remain “in the president’s chair forever” is “not good, and (is) detrimental for the country, and I do not need it as well.”

But when asked whether he would stand for the re-election in 2018, as the Russian constitution permits, Mr. Putin said, “it indeed allows but it does not mean that I will make such a decision. I will proceed from the general context, domestic understanding and my personal feelings.”

Russia’s constitution restricts the country’s president to two consecutive, six-year terms, requiring Mr. Putin to step down by 2024 at the latest. The Russian leader has repeatedly said before that he plans to abide by the term limits.

inset.p: We realize the malignity of the ‘iron curtain’ for us, and nobody is going to build a wall around us.

article-body.p: Mr. Putin said that it was too early to talk about the 2018 election, as there is “much time ahead, and a lot can change.”

Mr. Putin was first elected Russia’s president in 2000 and held the post for eight years before becoming prime minister—a post in which he retained much power. After four years, he returned to the presidency in 2012 for a new six-year term. Were he to win Russia’s election in 2018 and serve more than four years of his term, Mr. Putin would become the country’s longest-serving leader since Stalin, outstripping Leonid Brezhnev, who led the Soviet Union from 1964 to 1982.
Mr. Putin’s assurance that he will one day step down comes as some of the country’s business elite is growing nervous over the deepening confrontation with the West.

The Kremlin announced Sunday that Mr. Putin would sign an “alliance and strategic partnership” with Georgia’s breakaway region of Abkhazia on Monday—a move that is certain to draw protest from the Georgian capital, Tbilisi, and fuel fears that Mr. Putin is determined to expand Russia’s borders.

Russia recognized Abkhazia as independent along with South Ossetia following a five-day war with Tbilisi in 2008. Georgia’s Prime Minister Irakli Garibashvili said last week that recent Russian moves represented a huge step toward annexing the Georgian breakaway region of Abkhazia.

In the interview published on Sunday, Mr. Putin said Russia wasn’t planning to build a new “Iron Curtain” between itself and the West and wouldn’t permit anyone to isolate it. Russia isn’t building and won’t build new walls between the nations, Mr. Putin said. “We realize the malignity of the ‘Iron Curtain’ for us, and nobody is going to build a wall around us.”

Calling Western sanctions against Russia “a gross violation of human rights,” Mr. Putin said he stood behind the businessmen and officials targeted by the sanctions. They “are Russian nationals, they consider themselves patriots of this country and someone has decided they should be punished for this,” he said.
He said that by imposing the sanctions, the West was trying to “punish my friends, whom I am not going to abandon…to sow discord within the elites, and then maybe into the society.”
Mr. Putin’s words coincided with those of Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov, who on Saturday accused the West of “seeking regime change” in his country by imposing the sanctions against Moscow.

Russia has stepped up its war of words with the West as tensions remain at their highest since the Cold War amid the conflict in Ukraine. Since Moscow annexed Crimea in March and pro-Russia rebels have taken controls of parts of regions in Ukraine’s east, the U.S. and the European Union have imposed sanctions against dozens of Russian individuals and companies. The result has been an almost complete closure of international financial markets for Russian companies.
article-body.tagline: Alan Cullison contributed to this article.
article-body.p: Write to Alexander Kolyandr at Alexander.Kolyandr@wsj.com
